data.title: Surprise in Downtown Elizabeth
data.text: Elizabeth was a major Revolutionary War site, and actually has several historic sites to visit. Boxwood Hall is a lovely site, and the docent is terrific. The house is now stuck in-between various more modern buildings in downtown Elizabeth, and the side wings have been removed. It will take a bit of imagination to conjure what it must have been like in the 1700s, but it's an interesting visit and well-cared for property.

data.title: 1750 House boasts several famous occupants
data.text: Boxwood Hall was built around 1750 by Sam Woodruff, then mayor of Elizabethtown, before being sold to Elias Boudinot, the first president of the Continental Congress from 1782-83 . Situated as it is and crammed cheek to jowl among other buildings and houses in downtown Elizabeth, it takes a little imagination to picture how the mansion and its parklike grounds would have looked at the time of the Revolutionary War, but it was clearly built to impress with its soaring ceilings and spacious rooms. The downstairs rooms are furnished and you'll enjoy the knowledgeable docent's spiel about the various owners and occupants of this house.

data.title: Mansion de época!
data.text: Una interesante mansión de época, data del siglo 18 antes de la ndependencia americana. Tomamos unas fotos en el exterior. Vale darse una vuelta, están en Elizabeth.
